node.name: bgp
node.description: Top-level configuration and state for the BGP routerNone

node.name: global
node.description: Global configuration for the BGP routerNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the global BGP routerNone

node.name: as
node.description: Local autonomous system number of the router. Uses the 32-bit as-number type from the model in RFC 6991.None

node.name: router-id
node.description: Router id of the router - an unsigned 32-bit integer expressed in dotted quad notation.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to the global BGP routerNone

node.name: as
node.description: Local autonomous system number of the router. Uses the 32-bit as-number type from the model in RFC 6991.None

node.name: router-id
node.description: Router id of the router - an unsigned 32-bit integer expressed in dotted quad notation.None

node.name: total-paths
node.description: Total number of BGP paths within the contextNone

node.name: total-prefixes
node.description: Total number of BGP prefixes received within the contextNone

node.name: default-route-distance
node.description: Administrative distance (or preference) assigned to routes received from different sources (external, internal, and local).None

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the default route distanceNone

node.name: external-route-distance
node.description: Administrative distance for routes learned from external BGP (eBGP).None

node.name: internal-route-distance
node.description: Administrative distance for routes learned from internal BGP (iBGP).None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to the default route distanceNone

node.name: external-route-distance
node.description: Administrative distance for routes learned from external BGP (eBGP).None

node.name: internal-route-distance
node.description: Administrative distance for routes learned from internal BGP (iBGP).None

node.name: confederation
node.description: Parameters indicating whether the local system acts as part of a BGP confederationNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to BGP confederationsNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: When this leaf is set to true it indicates that the local-AS is part of a BGP confederationNone

node.name: identifier
node.description: Confederation identifier for the autonomous system.None

node.name: member-as
node.description: Remote autonomous systems that are to be treated as part of the local confederation.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to the BGP confederationsNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: When this leaf is set to true it indicates that the local-AS is part of a BGP confederationNone

node.name: identifier
node.description: Confederation identifier for the autonomous system.None

node.name: member-as
node.description: Remote autonomous systems that are to be treated as part of the local confederation.None

node.name: graceful-restart
node.description: Parameters relating the graceful restart mechanism for BGPNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information associated with graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.name: route-selection-options
node.description: Parameters relating to options for route selectionNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to route selection optionsNone

node.name: always-compare-med
node.description: Compare multi-exit discriminator (MED) value from different ASes when selecting the best route. The default behavior is to only compare MEDs for paths received from the same AS.None

node.name: ignore-as-path-length
node.description: Ignore the AS path length when selecting the best path. The default is to use the AS path length and prefer paths with shorter length.None

node.name: external-compare-router-id
node.description: When comparing similar routes received from external BGP peers, use the router-id as a criterion to select the active path.None

node.name: advertise-inactive-routes
node.description: Advertise inactive routes to external peers. The default is to only advertise active routes.None

node.name: enable-aigp
node.description: Flag to enable sending / receiving accumulated IGP attribute in routing updatesNone

node.name: ignore-next-hop-igp-metric
node.description: Ignore the IGP metric to the next-hop when calculating BGP best-path. The default is to select the route for which the metric to the next-hop is lowestNone

node.name: last-established
node.description:
This timestamp indicates the time that the BGP session last transitioned in or out of the Established state. The value is the timestamp in seconds relative to the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).
The BGP session uptime can be computed by clients as the difference between this value and the current time in UTC (assuming the session is in the ESTABLISHED state, per the session-state leaf).None

node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: connect-retry
node.description: Time interval in seconds between attempts to establish a session with the peer.None

node.name: hold-time
node.description: Time interval in seconds that a BGP session will be considered active in the absence of keepalive or other messages from the peer. The hold-time is typically set to 3x the keepalive-interval.None

node.description: Time interval in seconds between transmission of keepalive messages to the neighbor. Typically set to 1/3 the hold-time.None

node.name: minimum-advertisement-interval
node.description: Minimum time which must elapse between subsequent UPDATE messages relating to a common set of NLRI being transmitted to a peer. This timer is referred to as MinRouteAdvertisementIntervalTimer by RFC 4721 and serves to reduce the number of UPDATE messages transmitted when a particular set of NLRI exhibit instability.None

node.name: treat-as-withdraw

node.name: graceful-restart
node.description: Parameters relating the graceful restart mechanism for BGPNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information associated with graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only

node.name: advertise-inactive-routes

node.name: ignore-next-hop-igp-metric

node.description: Do not tear down the BGP session when the maximum prefix limit is exceeded, but rather only log a warning. The default of this leaf is false, such that when it is not specified, the session is torn down.None

node.name: shutdown-threshold-pct
node.description: Threshold on number of prefixes that can be received from a neighbour before generation of warning messages or log entries. Expressed as a percentage of max-prefixesNone

node.name: restart-timer
node.description: Time interval in seconds after which the BGP session is re-established after being torn down due to exceeding the max-prefix limit.None
